Let  $\textstyle a_{n}=f^{(n)}(a)/n!$  , so that for any  $\alpha$  wehave  $|a_{n}|>n^{n}$  .By Hadamard’s formula, the radius of convergence is given by 

$$
{\frac{1}{R}}=\operatorname*{lim}_{n\to\infty}|a_{n}|^{1/n}=\operatorname*{lim}_{n\to\infty}n=\infty
$$
 
so that thepower seriesdefined in the right hand side is valid only at  $a$  .Yet, as an analytic functior it should be analytic in some radius of convergence for  $R>0$  Of course,if  $g(n)$  is any increasing function(insteadof  $n^{n}$  )suchthat  $g(n)\to\infty$  ,then we arrive at the same conclusion. 
Here's another way to go about theproblem,which seems to be more of whatAhlfors intended by putting this problem here.Cauchy'sestimate tellsus thatif  $R>0$  二一心 

$$
|f^{(n)}(z)|\leq\frac{n!M}{R^{n}}
$$
 
where  $M=\mathrm{max}_{|z|=R}\left|f(z)\right|$  .Note that  $M$  is finite since  $f(z)$  is continuous and  $|z|=R$  is compact. If also  $|f^{(n)}(z)|>n!n^{n}$  ,then  $n^{n}\,\leq\,M/R^{n}$   for all  $n\geq0$  For  $\mathcal{n}$  large enough this inequality fails since we can rearrange it to  $(n R)^{n}\leq M$  ,and thelefthand side is unboundedfor every  $R>0$  
4.2.3.6.A more general form of Lemma 3 reads as follows 
Let the function  $\varphi(z,t)$  be continuous as a function of both variables when  $\mathcal{Z}$  lies in a region  $\Omega$  and  $a\leq t\leq b$  .Suppose further that  $\varphi(z,t)$  is analytic as a function of  $z\in\Omega$  for any fixed  $t$  .Then 

$$
F(z)=\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(z,t)\ d t
$$
 
is analytic in  $\mathcal{L}$  and 

$$
F^{\prime}(z)=\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}{\frac{\partial\varphi(z,t)}{\partial z}}\ d t\qquad\qquad(\star).
$$
 
To prove thisrepresent  $\varphi(z,t)$  as a Cauchy integral 

$$
\varphi(z,t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C}\frac{\varphi(\zeta,t)}{\zeta-z}\ d\zeta.
$$
 
Fill in the necessary details to obtain 

$$
F(z)=\int_{C}\left({\frac{1}{2\pi i}}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(\zeta,t)\;d t\right){\frac{d\zeta}{\zeta-z}}.
$$
 
anduseLemma3toprove  $(\star)$  
Solution:Recall that Cauchy's integral formula tells us that 

$$
f(z)={\frac{1}{2\pi i}}\int_{C}{\frac{f(\zeta)\ d\zeta}{\zeta-z}}
$$
 
for  $\mathcal{Z}$  in the bounded region determined by  $C$  .Applying this with  $F(z)$  gives 

$$
F(z)={\frac{1}{2\pi i}}\int_{C}{\frac{F(\zeta)\ d\zeta}{\zeta-z}}={\frac{1}{2\pi i}}\int_{C}\left(\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(\zeta,t)\ d t\right){\frac{d\zeta}{\zeta-z}}=\int_{C}\left({\frac{1}{2\pi i}}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(\zeta,t)\ d t\right){\frac{d\zeta}{\zeta-z}}
$$
 
(one may also view it as a consequence of Fubini's theorem). Defining  $\begin{array}{r}{\Phi(\zeta)=1/2\pi i\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(\zeta,t)\ d t,}\end{array}$  Lemma 3 tells us that 

$$
F^{\prime}(z)=\int_{C}\frac{\Phi(\zeta)~d\zeta}{(\zeta-z)^{2}}=\int_{C}\left(\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\varphi(\zeta,t)~d t\right)\frac{d\zeta}{(\zeta-z)^{2}}.
$$
 
NowapplyLemma3oncemoreto  $\varphi(z,t)$  directly 

$$
\frac{\partial\varphi(z,t)}{\partial z}=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C}\frac{\varphi(\zeta,t)\;d\zeta}{(\zeta-z)^{2}}.
$$
 
Integrating this over  $\alpha\leq t\leq\beta$  and using Fubini's theorem to switch integrals gives the result 
4.3.Local Properties of Analytical Functions.
